data.title: Claudiu Stan | Rutgers SAS-Newark
data.snippet:
His research at Rutgers includes the study of phase transitions and ultrafast dynamics in liquids and soft matter, metastable liquid water (supercooled water, and water at negative pressures), developing new applications for X-ray lasers, and delivering liquid samples for extreme-intensity lasers.

## Research Initiatives

Investigating and triggering phase transitions in metastable water with X-ray free-electron lasers.

Investigation of rapid and nonlinear fluid dynamics phenomena associated with the rapid serial diffraction measurements at MHz X-ray lasers.

Liquid sample delivery for experiments at petawatt laser facilities.

## Education

Postdoctoral Fellow, Harvard University. Advisor: George M. Whitesides

Ph.D., Physics, MIT, (2005) Advisor: Wolfgang Ketterle [...] ## Publications

Selected Recent Publications:

A. Kalita, M. Mrozek-McCourt, T. F. Kaldawi, P. R. Willmott, N.-T. D. Loh, S. Marte, R. G. Sierra, H. Laksmono, J. E. Koglin, M. J. Hayes, R. H. Paul, S. A. H. Guillet, A. L. Aquila, M. Liang, S. Boutet, and C. A. Stan. Microstructure and crystal order during freezing of supercooled water drops, Nature 620, 557 (2023).

C. A. Stan, A. Kalita, S. Marte, T. F. Kaldawi, P. R. Willmott and S. Boutet. Rocket drops: The self-propulsion of supercooled freezing drops, Phys. Rev. Fluids 8, L021601 (2023). [...] Ph.D., Physics, MIT, (2005) Advisor: Wolfgang Ketterle

B.Sc., Technological Physics, University of Bucharest (1999)

## Courses Taught

Introduction To Modern Physics (21:750:316)  
General Physics I (21:750:203)  
General Physics II (21:750:204)  
Physics Seminar (21:750:491)  
Special Topics in Experimental Physics (26:755:610)  
Doctoral Seminar (26:755:791)

## Expertise

Ultrafast molecular and nanoscale dynamics, X-ray lasers, microfluidics, phase transitions, metastable liquids, biophysics.

## Publications

Selected Recent Publications:

data.title: Claudiu Schirda - Magnetic Resonance Research Center
data.snippet:
### Education & Training

1. Schirda, C., Tanase, C. and Boada F, Rosette Spectroscopic Imaging: Optimal Parameters for Artifact-free, High Sensitivity Spectroscopic Imaging (Journal of Magnetic Resonance Imaging, 2009 Jun;29(6):1375-85., PMID 19472411)

2. Zivadinov R, Schirda C, Dwyer MG, Haacke ME, Weinstock-Guttman B, Menegatti E, Heininen-Brown M, Magnano C, Malagoni AM, Wack DS, Hojnacki D, Kennedy C, Carl E, Bergsland N, Hussein S, Poloni G, Bartolomei I, Salvi F, and Zamboni P: Chronic cerebrospinal venous insufficiency and iron deposition on susceptibility-weighted imaging in patients with multiple sclerosis: a pilot case-control study. Int Angiol. 2010 Apr;29(2):158-75. PMID 20351672. [...] My main research interest is in developing and optimizing fast, high sensitivity 2D & 3D spectroscopic imaging data acquisition techniques at high (3T) and ultra-high (7T) field, using non-Cartesian gradient readout waveforms and robust LCModel quantification, and applying these techniques primarily in studies of neurodegenerative disorders but also for liver and leg 1H and 31P fast magnetic resonance spectroscopy imaging (MRSI). In addition, I am interested in developing objective quantification techniques for CSF flow rates in the aqueduct of Sylvius, studying stem cells in vivo using MRS, and optimizing phase-contrast high-res multi-echo SWI acquisitions for brain iron quantification and T2\ and T2’ imaging. After completing my PhD in 2007, I worked as an MRI physicist at Buffalo [...] 6. Claudiu Schirda, Tiejun Zhao, Julie Pan, and Hoby Hetherington, Rosette Spectroscopic Imaging with Hadamard Encoding. In Proceedings of the 23rd Annual Meeting of ISMRM, Toronto, Canada, 2015. Abstract 987.

7. Schirda CV., Zhao T., Andronesi OC, Lee Y., Pan, JW, Mountz JM, Hetherington HP and Boada, F, In vivo brain rosette spectroscopic imaging (RSI) with LASER excitation, constant gradient strength readout, and automated LCModel quantification for all voxels. Magnetic Resonance in Medicine, 2016 Aug;76(2):380-90, PMID 26308482.

8. Claudiu Schirda, Tiejun Zhao, Hoby Hetherington, Victor Yushmanov, and Jullie Pan, Rosette Spectroscopic Imaging (RSI) of human brain at 7T. In Proceedings of the 24th Annual Meeting of ISMRM, Singapore, 2016. Abstract 2351

data.title: Claudiu Bandea | Profiles - eLife
data.snippet:
Briefly, in order to prove or disprove a viral etiology of TSEs, the proponents of the viral etiology, as well as those promoting the prion hypothesis, searched for viral nucleic acids (DNA or RNA) in the material transmitting the disease, which seemed to be a rational scientific approach. After decades of research and dozens of studies, which failed to detect viral nucleic acids in the transmitting material (i.e. the scrapie inoculum), the prion hypothesis triumphed: “While no single experiment can refute the existence of the “scrapie virus”, all of the data taken together from numerous experimental studies present an impressive edifice which argues that the 50-year quest for a virus has failed because it does not exist!” ( [...] “A frequent source of material for Bik’s sleuthing is PLOS ONE, which has retracted 22 papers after Bik identified problematic figures. David Knutson, a spokesman for the publication, says her work has been good for the journal, and science generally. “PLOS ONE greatly appreciates researchers like Dr. Bik who are committed to the integrity of the published literature, and who volunteer their time to critically assess published articles and notify journals of any concerns,” Knutson tells The Scientist and Retraction Watch.” [...] Additionally, the OPR will incentivize researchers to produce results and ideas that can stand immediate and vigorous scrutiny, thereby discouraging the publication of questionable or unreproducible studies ( ). This would not only revolutionize science but would give researchers the opportunity to redirect their work towards more productive and meaningful projects.

The case for an Open-ended Peer Review (OPR) process supported by grants
